definitions.definition: a line or surface that bends gradually; a smooth bend

examples.text: The pattern was made up of straight lines and curves.
He admired the delicate curve of her ear.
The seats were arranged to form a curve.
the curve of his neck
the natural curve of your spine

definitions.definition: a place where a road bends or turns

examples.text: a curve in the road
The driver lost control on a curve and the vehicle hit a tree.
He slowed down to negotiate the curve.
Slow down at the curves.
The car vanished around a curve.
The road follows the coast in a wide curve.
The road went around in a tight curve.

definitions.definition: a line on a graph that shows how one quantity varies compared with another

examples.text: The program automatically plots the curve on a graph.
This figure shows the population curve for the last hundred years.
a demand/yield/growth/supply curve
the unemployment-income curve *(= showing the relationship between the number of unemployed people and national income)*

definitions.definition: a ball that moves in a curve when it is thrown to the batter
something that is unexpected and difficult to deal with
curving shapes that form part of a woman's body

examples.text: The supermodel showed off her famous curves in a figure-hugging red dress.
The evening dress hugged her curves beautifully.

definitions.definition: in advance of or behind a particular trend

examples.text: Our expert advice will help you stay ahead of the curve.
We've fallen behind the curve when it comes to developing new digital products.

definitions.definition: to manage the rate or quantity of something so that it does not increase too much within a short period of time

examples.text: These measures are intended to flatten the curve of new infections in order to reduce the load on hospitals.

wordOrigin: late Middle English: from Latin curvare ‘to bend’, from curvus ‘bent’. The noun dates from the late 17th cent.
